alert.note: Alert for Bladen; Cumberland (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wilmington (Northeastern South Carolina and Southeastern North Carolina - Wilmington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 10 at 11:17AM EDT until April 15 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North Carolina... Cape Fear River At Elizabethtown affecting Bladen County. Cape Fear River At William O Huske Lock And Dam 3 affecting Cumberland and Bladen Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina... Black Creek At Quinby affecting Darlington and Florence Counties. Great Pee Dee River At Pee Dee affecting Florence and Marion Counties. ...The Flood Warning is cancelled for the following rivers in North Carolina... Lumber River Near Lumberton affecting Robeson County. For the Cape Fear River...including William O Huske Lock And Dam 3, Elizabethtown, Lock And Dam 1...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Lumber River...including Nichols, Pembroke, Lumberton Usgs Gage, Maxton, Lumberton, Boardman...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Great Pee Dee River...including Pee Dee, Bennettsville 10sw...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Black Creek...including Black Creek Nr Hartsville, Quinby... Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY SATURDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Cape Fear River At William O Huske Lock And Dam 3. * WHEN...Until early Saturday afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 48.0 feet, The access road for the wildlife boat ramp at Tar Heel Ferry Road may be flooded. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:00 AM EDT Monday the stage was 48.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 49.0 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage early Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 42.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Additional information is available at water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=ilm . The next statement will be issued by this evening.
